text: Night is falling in a forgotten part of the city. The street-lights are a joke - three out of four are dead Only a large moon and some cloud-streaked stars illuminat dark and derelict street. Once the hub of an industrial area, now the buildings are abandoned, the sidewalks choked with litter and debris. are boarded-up, windows are glassless, walls are graffiti At various points, several BUMS warm their hands at trash fires.
- as their eyes move, following something moving down the street.  Heard OFF is the sound of a smooth and powerful engine.

Down this boulevard of decay and despair drives an incongruously expensive car - a Range Rover. A rich kid i going shopping. The car cruises the ruins until it pulls up outside the o open store on the block.

A dim light bulb shines within - the only indicator that store is still trading.  Its windows are grimy, its door defaced.  Above the door - barely legible through the acc dirt of city years - a sign; CARDUCCI'S ANTIQUES AND CURI

The side door opens - helped on its way by the kick of an expensive leather boot - and JP MONROE steps out. JP is 24, rich, handsome, and spoiled. His hair is slick designer-grease, his slim frame is wrapped in a $600 leat jacket. For a moment he surveys the store and casts contemptuous glances up and down the ruined street.  He shows no anxie being in this twilight part of town.  Cocooned in the confidence of wealth, he's never felt threatened in his l Satisfied he's in the right place, he walks confidently t the doorway.

The store itself looks like an antique - old wood panelli shelving, Victorian display cases, and faded wallpaper. grimy, dusty, and dimly-lit - and apparently unattended. It is packed with merchandise - shelves and aisles overfl onto the floor making the place a maze to walk through. The stock is a strange surreal mix.  Discarded items from America (Norge fridges, toasters, Frankie Lymon albums) s space with older items; framed pictures, Victorian automa wax dolls, and (a specialty of the store?) items of punis stocks, iron boots, chastity belts, whips. Could that rea be an Electric Chair glimpsed in the shadowed back of the

He wanders through the merchandise, casting appraising gl at some items.  Some he even runs his hands over - grimac the dust and grime they leave on his fingers.  But his ma suggests he is looking for something specific. Near the room's center is an old hoarding from the dead d vaudeville and travelling shows.  It is tall and broad an leaning against something behind it.
- which is colorfully and garishly decorated and full of hyperbolic come-ons to long-dead punters:

head_text.subj: AN EDUCATIONAL SHOW FOR ALL THE FAMILY PRESENTED UNDER TH
AUSPICES OF PROFESSOR EMMANUEL BOCKLIN, TRAGEDIAN AND

text: - as he moves the hoarding aside.
Wow ...

REVEALED is a six-foot tall black rectangular pillar, cov in beautifully detailed 3-D carvings all in the same matt finish as the pillar itself.  The pillar is extremely biz as if a New York avant-garde sculptor has interpreted a T Pole for jaded modern tastes.  The carvings are of dead r copulating skeletons,  filigree-patterned boxes, and face One of these faces - recognizable to the audience but not - is the ossified visage of PINHEAD, the demon from the f two HELLRAISER pictures.
- as he leans in to study this face, already fascinated b calm cruelty and promise of dark wisdom. A voice OFF startles him.
You want it?
JP whirls round in shock.  A BUM is standing close to him

He has long matted black hair and a similarly greasy bear His eyes are a piercing, excited blue.  Otherwise he is indistinguishable from those we saw on the street outside ragged, tatty clothes, features blackened with grime.
- as he glances round the store and past the bum to the d beyond; has this character just wandered in from the stre
Is it yours?
The Bum smiles, shaking his head knowingly.
No.  Not mine.  Yours.
JP nods, still a little uncertain.
How much do you want for it?
Whatever you think its worth.

JP digs a hand into his back pocket and pulls out a wad o cash.  Without counting or checking, he proffers it. The Bum's hand flies out and siezes JP's, pressing the mo between their palms, making the exchange into a handclasp In the background, OUT OF FOCUS, is Pinhead's face on the pillar.
Enjoy ...
The FOCUS switches so that the hands in foreground BLUR a Pinhead's frozen face becomes SHARP, as if he is silently watching this deal take place. The Bum's hand moves away with the money as we
BLACKNESS.   Voice OVER.
It's a mystery to me ...

SMASH-CUT to full-frame VIDEO IMAGE image of JOANNE SUMMERSKILL, standing and looking directly into camera, a we are watching a TV broadcast.  In shot behind her is a hospital Emergency Room - no patients, no staff, just bed intensive-care equipment. Joanne - or JOEY, as she prefers to be called - is 23 yea old, an attractive and clever brunette, with a quiet sadn her eyes that she usually manages to keep almost hidden. Dressed in the stylish but sedate garb of a TV newsperson holds a microphone marked with the logo of her station, W Her direct address to the unseen TV camera continues.

Most nights this inner-city Emergency Room would be a chaos of blood and panic and grace under pressure.  But tonight, as you see, it's like Death took a holiday.  It's a mystery to me ... A mystery how those assholes at Assignments knew it.  This is Joey Summerskill for W-QQY.  Emergency Room. No story.  Really, really pissed off.

Despite the nature of her last few words, Joey has ironic kept up the manner and delivery of a newscaster.  Now, sh breaks mood, looks away from the camera, and, with a dism wave of the hand, begins to walk out of shot.
Ah, break it down, Doc.  It's a bust.

- to reveal that we are not watching a broadcast at all b are in the ER in real time.  As well as Joey, the room co her cameraman ("DOC" FISHER) and an ER NURSE. Doc - a 45 year old with a weight problem, a nicotine addiction, and a cynical attitude - lowers a shoulder-mou Video camera and watches Joey walk to a water-cooler agai wall. His expression is a mix of exasperation and sympath The Nurse is a middle-aged woman of Asian ancestry.  She puzzled expression as she addresses Doc.
She can talk like this on television? She can say this thing?  This assholes?
Doc replies but keeps his eyes on Joey as he crosses to h
No sweat, sweetheart.  It's for the European satellite ....  Joey; rein it in, kid.  They couldn't've known.
Joey sucks angrily at water from a paper-cup and then cru and bins the cup like an act of revenge.
I know.  I know.  But it's just so ... neat, isn't it?  The first gig that isn't cute kids or diet gurus and it's taken away from me.
Yeah, well like you said - it's a mystery.  But that's all it is. Mystery.  Not malice.  What, you think the station paid off every accident victim in the city to ... ?
Doc is interrupted by the RINGING of a cell-phone he has holstered at his waist.  He picks it up.
Speak.
Doc.  24th and Cedar.  Fast.  Hostage situation.
OK.  Listen - Joey's here.  Shall ...
No need.  Martin's already there. Hurry.  You've got ambulances to beat.
The line goes dead.  Doc looks at Joey.  She heard it all shrugs apologetically.
Better hurry, Doc.  A real story.  With a real reporter.
Joey ....  Look, you wanna ride?  I can go by your place.
You'd lose the money-shots.  No.  I'll catch a bus.  Or a cab.  Don't worry about it.  Go.
OK.  Be careful.  And lighten up.  Story of your life could be right round the corner.
That is the story of my life.

With a rueful smile, Joey watches Doc leave. Joey and the Nurse exchange glances - Joey's impassive bu vaguely friendly, the Nurse's a little disapproving; if t camera's gone, what the hell are YOU still doing here?

Joey makes her solitary way along a medium-length corrido that has two sets of double swing doors at either end, on giving on to the ER, the other toward an exit.  Joey is h for the latter, her mood sad and defeated.
Suddenly - SMASH! - the doors burst open from the other s

The mood is suddenly fast and urgent as a gurney is wheel rapidly through the doors. Two PARAMEDICS, both male, both about Joey's age, are pus the gurney at a run and talking rapidly to each other.  T completely ignore Joey and also ignore the TEENAGE GIRL w running beside the gurney. The girl - TERRI - is 18 or 19.  She is a pale-faced blon dressed as if for a Desperately-Seeking-Susan party and i keeping up a stream of chatter as if rehearsing excuses. As Joey flattens herself against the corridor wall to let pass, it is neither the paramedics nor Terri that get her attention.  It is the BOY on the gurney.

The teenage boy lies flat on his back semi-conscious, his eyelids fluttering, his breathing shallow. Horribly, shockingly, dangling from his face and body are heavy chains that drag and rattle along the corridor floo There are at least sixteen of them and they seem firmly b in his skin.
The DIALOGUE as the gurney is rushed to the ER doors is R FIRE and OVERLAPPED, the Paramedics responding only to ea other and ignoring the two girls comments and questions.
It wasn't my fault.  It wasn't my fault.
10 milligram IV Valium stat.  How the fuck did this happen ... ?!
It was outside.  I wasn't even with him.
You ever see anything like this before?
He must have stolen it.
What's going on?
Yeah, sure.  Five times a fucking day. Just push!
Once the gurney has passed her, Joey runs along behind it
It was off the statue.  In the club.
What happened to him?
Think they'll get him back?
It's nothing to do with me.
Worst case of status I've seen.  Even money at best.
The foot of the gurney slams into the ER doors and the Paramedics slide it rapidly through.
Wait!  I'm a reporter!  Tell me where he was ...

The Nurse and a middle-aged DOCTOR are seen through the d preparing emergency equipment.  The Doctor already has fibrillator pads in his hands. The Paramedics follow the gurney through and, turning rap push the doors closed from the inside.
Joey and Terri are alone, excluded from the ER activity. turns to speak but Terri is already halfway to the other Joey runs after her.
Hold on.  Hold on, please.  I need talk to you.
(over her shoulder) It's nothing to do with me.  I wasn't even with him.

Joey catches up with her a couple of yards short of the d She grabs at her arm to slow her down. Terri turns, snatching her arm away in a sudden moment of anger.  She backs toward the doors, making gestures of dismissal and denial with her hands.
Look, lady!  I told you!  It's not my problem!  I was just there!
Where?
Under The Underground.  Can I like GO now?!
Under the Underground?  What's that? Where is ...

Suddenly, the conversation is interrupted by a shattering loud SCREAM, agonized and terrified, coming from the ER. Both girls freeze but then their reactions are very diffe Joey turns instantly and runs back toward the ER.  Terri watches her for a beat and then heads through the other d The SCREAM continues, a howling horrible sound. Joey reaches the ER doors and throws them open.  And free terrified shock.
- is on the floor, as if flung there by some powerful for The fibrillator pads are still in his hands and his expre is awe-struck and disbelieving.
- is cowering behind a mobile tray of surgical instrument muttering to herself and making the gesture of the cross.
- are flattened against the far wall, terror on their fac

The Boy is on the emergency table.  It's him that's screa His body is arched tight in shock, eyes and mouth wide op He's wired up to an ECG and the MONITOR shows a heartbeat should be measured on the Richter scale. The chains - all still connected to his face and his body rigid and tight, being pulled straight up into the air as tugged taut by invisible hands. The boy's skin is stretched and pulled at those points wh the chains are connected to him and it seems horribly pos that his flesh will burst if the pressure continues. The scene is held for a terrible frozen moment.  Then sud the chains drop, the scream stops, and the boy's body slu There is a massive ELECTRICAL SURGE.  The ECG flat-lines it and the other monitors go haywire, sparking and splutt

The lights in the room flicker and strobe. The fibrillator pads arc angrily. The Doctor flings them ELECTRIC ENERGY seems to run along the slumped chains and disappear as if dissolved in some impossible electric mel Lighting and machinery return to normal (ECG still flat-l and the medical staff stare thunder-struck at the dead bo For the first time, the other people in the ER become awa Joey's presence in the doorway.
Who's that?  Get her out of here!
The Nurse heads for the doors.  Joey is already backing a
- as Joey backs away, an expression of numbed shock on he face.  The doors close over, blocking her out.
- still arcing.
CLOSE on flickering neon light in the bus cabin.
- glancing at the light from her seat.

The bus is almost deserted.  Three other passengers - A P BAG LADY, and A WINO - are spread out around the interior seem lost in worlds of their own but their vacant alienat stares highlight Joey's isolation and tension.  Fear has entered her life. The bus moves through the neon-lit loneliness of downtown streets.
- her face, lit by reflected store-signs and street-light lost and distant, as if she is submerged in some dream-se memory and sadness.

head_text.subj: INT. TV STATION, EDITING SUITE DAY

text: A wall of TV monitors, each monitor showing Joey sitting couch with a painfully thin older woman - BRITTANY VERTUE Brittany's probably 50 but her face is as tight and smoot surgery can make it.  She is dressed in the standard unif the health-avatar; brightly-colored leotard over black ti Joey has a big paperback book - BEYOND HUNGER; THE BRITTA VERTUE GUIDE TO HOLISTIC DIETING - which she holds to cam She smiles and, turning to face Brittany, crosses her leg The image freezes.  And replays.  Joey crosses her legs a And again.  And again.
(over) See?  This is what I mean.  Your technique is all wrong.

Joey (in real time) is sitting in an easy chair in the ed suite looking at the wall of monitors. BRAD, a techie in his late-twenties, and DOC FISHER are i swivel chairs immediately in front of the video console. All three are drinking coffee.  Doc is smoking a cigarett
(guardedly) What do you mean?
I mean hardly any thigh.  I'm telling you, Joey; shorter skirt, more lift on the leg-cross ... and you're made.
Doc chuckles in a half-friendly, half-sleazy way.
Fuck you.
What, you think I'm kidding?  I guarantee it.  An inch more flank.  Boys upstairs get hot.  Bingo, you're an anchor-woman.
(to herself) Jesus Christ ...
Ah, give her a break.
Doc leans over and stops the tape.
(to Doc) What's with you?
He swivels his chair round to face Joey.
C'mon, Joey.  I'm just trying to help you hit a home run here.
Yeah?  Well, you just struck out.  It may be a surprise to you, Brad, but I want to do it the right way.  Not tight skirts.  Tight stories.
Right.  Like last night's doozie.
I know what I saw.
And I believe what you say.  But this is TV.  No pictures, no story.
Yeah, too bad I had to go and ...
... and cover something on Planet Earth. See, you gotta remember, Joey; this is a LOCAL station.  As in local to this galaxy.
Joey slams her coffee mug down and stands up.
There's a story out there.
(jumping in warningly) Not on station time.
No.  Not on station time.  My story.  My time.
Joey exits.  Brad watches her leave with a half-smile on face then turns to Doc.
Lot of attitude there, Doc ...
He starts up the video tape again and, on the monitors, J once again crosses her legs on the couch.
... but great legs.

CLOSE on a screaming male face, twisted as in pain or fur PULL BACK rapidly to REVEAL the face belongs to the lead of THANATOS.  He is on a nightclub stage with the rest of band, all of them dressed in that shit-poor-white-trash-o look favored by all such rich young businessmen with guit A tatty banner across the back of the stage proclaims: UN THE UNDERGROUND PRESENTS THANATOS. The SCREAM ends, replaced with the roaring thunder of dru guitars as Thanatos kick into some thrash-metal. The dance-floor of the club is packed with KIDS dancing t incredibly fast, incredibly loud music. Many of the kids favor the same look as the band but it's exclusive; college types are there too, along with some and female - sporting the glitz-meets-sleaze look of Terr The club itself is of course dimly-lit and the basic deco black.  Where it is distinguished from hundreds of others the bizarre sculptures and pieces of artwork that hang fr ceiling and walls, all in tones of black, silver and gray

A headless, armless torso wrapped in barbed wire. A pair of male and female heads.  Bonsai-like trees grow every orifice - eye-sockets, nostrils, ears, and mouths. A human arm with the skin and flesh of its upper half pee open and pinned out to reveal inside - instead of bone an sinew - an entire miniature metropolis, beautifully detai A black bird cage containing a fetal skeleton.

Kids also crowd the bar and the tables on the outskirts o dance floor.  It is a hot, sweaty, faintly aggressive atmosphere - people jostling for position, shouting to be heard, etc etc. The camera finds Joey - incongruous by dress and demeanor pushing her way among the crowd. The music is too loud and overpowering to hear Joey's voi it is clear as she moves through the confines of the club she is approaching various people and enquiring after Ter
- shake their heads and shrug.
- stares blankly and blinks.
- giggle, purse their lips, shake their heads.

- catches sight of a blonde figure moving across the danc floor and pushes through the crowd to follow.  She taps t figure's arm but, as it turns, she realizes it is a man 70's revivalist GLITTER-ROCKER.  He looks quizzically at Joey's mouth moves and this time she seems to get some response.  The Glitter-Rocker mouths a name. Joey can't hear him.  She hands him a business card and a He scrawls a name on the back of the card and Joey nods h thanks as he moves on.
- as Joey reads the name "Terri" on it.  She flips the ca reveal her name and number and writes "Terri - Please cal
- as Joey pushes to the counter and hands the card to a B who looks at it, nods, and puts it beneath the counter.
- as Joey makes her way out.

Camera moves into the tightly-packed throng on the dance making its way slowly toward the previously unseen center The crowd parts slightly to reveal, in the direct center floor, the tall black pillar from the opening sequence. The pillar is mounted on a plinth and spins as the client dance around it.  It seems very in keeping with the decor the club but even so it is a strong unsettling presence. The pillar has been mounted upside down, so that it looks odder than our first glimpse of it.  Near the bottom the inverted face of Pinhead, black and frozen, can be seen. The camera begins to spin around the pillar in contrary m to the pillar's own movement and, as it does so, draws cl and closer making for a disorienting, vertiginous image. As this happens, the raucous sound of the band Thanatos b to fade into a whirl of ECHO and to be replaced by a whir spinning, sound which we only recognize fully as we

The screen is filled with dense jungle foliage. The chugging spinning sound is now identifiable as the so Helicopter blades, one element of a SOUND MONTAGE conveyi sense and feel of a Jungle War; Helicopters in flight, ma gun fire, distant explosions, confused shouts and cries. A POV camera pushes its way through the lush, humid green The camera seems to be searching for something, glancing way and that, shoving leaves and tall grass aside. Voices begin to emerge clearly from the SOUND MASS off-sc as if the unseen seeker is getting nearer to his or her g
(off) Call for a Medi-Vac!
(off) Don't die, man!  Don't fucking die!

The dialogue prompts a more furious effort on the part of POV camera.  Pushing frantically through the obscuring fo it finally gains a clearer view and stops, looking ahead. In a tiny clearing, ten feet from the camera, still parti obscured by the jungle, two camouflage-clad SOLDIERS lean the prone body of a third.  It is unclear due to distance there is a lot of blood on the Soldier's body and uniform A new sound joins the SOUND MONTAGE - a persistent, rhyth ringing sound.  The other elements die away until only th left and we recognize it as the sound of a telephone as w

Joey jerks upright in bed as the ringing continues.  Conf and disoriented, her eyes fly around her darkened bedroom she's trying to understand where she is and what is happe Finally, she registers the phone and leans toward her bed table to pick it up.
- favoring the luminous display of an alarm clock next to phone.  Its warm green figures show the time is 2:35.
(off. Sleepily) God.  This better be birth, marriage, or death ...
- as she picks up the handset and puts it to her ear.
Uh-huh?
(on phone) Uh ... Hi!  Is this ... er ... Joanne Summerskill?
Joey.  Yeah, who is this?
You like ... left me a card?  At the club?
Right.  Right!
Joey swings out of bed to sit on the edge, much more aler
Right ... So ... Well, what do you want?
I want to talk to you.  We met ... now, listen, don't hang up, OK? ... We met at the hospital last night.
Oh yeah.  Yeah.  Well ... Look, I'll make a deal with you ... My boyfriend threw me out, right?  I'll trade you. You give me couch-space.  I'll give you talk.  OK?
Joey can't resist another glance at the clock.
Yeah.  Sure.  You mean ... tonight?
(Surprised at Joey's surprise. Bit of a culture clash here) Of course tonight.  Is that a problem? Like, if you've got a guy there or something ...
No.  No.  It's fine.  Come now.  I was having bad dreams anyway.

head_text.subj: INT. MAIN ROOM, JOEY'S APT. NIGHT

text: CLOSE on the front door of the apartment as it opens to r Terri leaning against the doorframe. Clad identically to how we last saw her, Terri clutches a stuffed leather bag, containing all her worldly possessio
Hi.  How're you doing?
Not waiting for either reply or invitation, she moves for
- as Terri walks past the dressing-gowned Joey and heads straight for Joey's sofa and sprawls on it, laying her ba the floor beside her.
You got anything to drink?
Joey closes the door, raised eyebrows registering her sli disapproval at Terri's cavalier attitude.  Her voice, how is polite.
I put some decaf on.  Er ... make yourself comfortable.
Right.
Joey walks past Terri and through to her kitchen, from wh hear the sound of COFFEE BEING POURED. Terri looks around at Joey's room.

The large and spacious room suggests that even if Joey is dissatisfied with her job she's at least being paid enoug make it bearable.  The room is very ordered, very neat, b stops short of being prissy. A very large picture window takes up all of one wall.  At moment of course the drapes are closed.  Another wall is up by a huge shelf unit packed with books, videos, and CD Joey's obsession with "getting the whole story" seems to true of her personal life as well as her professional.
- having finished her quick examination, she calls out.
So ... what was your bad dream?
Joey re-enters, carrying two mugs of coffee.
What?
Your dream.  You said you were having a bad dream.
Oh yeah ...
She hands one coffee to Terri and sits opposite her.
... well, I've been having it for years. It's not a nightmare or anything.  It's ... well, I know what it is.
What is it?
Why are you so interested?
Sorry.
No.  No, it's OK.  I ... It's my father.
(sympathetic, knowing) Oh, right.  Did he used to ... ?

God, no!  Nothing like that.  No, he died before I was born.  He died in Vietnam.  I never knew him.  Never met him.  We don't even know the details.  I dream of battlefields.  Of searching. Of trying to find out.
That's great.
What?

No ... I mean, it's not like great about your dad or anything.  It's just I don't dream.  Never have.  ... Maybe it'd help if I slept sometime ... Just kidding ... No, so it's always neat for me to hear about dreams.  I'm jealous.  It's like everybody has another world except me. You know what I mean?
I know what you're saying but ... Never? You've never had a dream?  No, you know, you do.  You must.  What you mean is you don't remember them.
Whatever.  All I know is - this is it for me.  Just me, my bag, and a series of shithead boyfriends.  It'd be good to see something else.  Have a nighttime life.  Be somebody different.
Terri pauses, then smiles like she's just realized someth
Hey ... this is great, isn't it?  Just girls talking.  Like having a conversation?  Good coffee.  You got a cigarette?
Joey waits, letting herself catch up with Terri's good-na but marginally strung-out personality.  She looks around room as if trying to remember where there are cigarettes.
Uh ...  yeah.  Yeah, somewhere.  Wait a minute.

Joey crosses to the big shelf-unit and pulls out a concea pack of cigarettes, a Zippo lighter, and an ashtray from a shelf of videos.  We notice that the videos are THE WOR WAR, volumes 1 thru 26.  She brings the smokes to Terri.
Great.  Thanks.  You gonna have one?
I'm trying to quit.
Oh, go on.  Have one.  Fuck it.  You think you're going to live forever?

She smiles and proffers the pack to Joey who shrugs, smil and takes one.  Terri picks up the Zippo and sparks it. A FLAME leaps out of the lighter, producing an instant of t from Terri.  Joey pulls the lighter back from Terri and c the lid extinguishing the flame.  Terri draws a book of m from her pocket shakily attempts to light her cigarette.
Sorry.  It was my father's.  It's temperamental.
It's okay.  It's just someone burned me once.
Joey takes the book of matches from Terri's hands and lig both cigarettes.  Terri takes a long, fearful look at the burning flame and then takes a deep, calming drag of her cigarette.

Wanna know how I look at it?  Way I see it is ... you give up, right?  Three days later, you get hit by a fucking truck and you know - you just KNOW  that your last thought as you go under those wheels'd be "Jesus H. Christ, I coulda smoked another three packs!"
She lays the book of matches down.  Joey's eyes go to the
Black letters on the dark-grey cover: UNDER THE UNDERGROU
Terri's eyes flick to the match-book and her mood changes becoming subdued and a little sullen.
Oh.  You wanna talk about that stuff.
Yes I do.  Terri, something awful happened to that boy.  I have to find out what it was.
But I don't know anything!  Really.  I just came out of the club and the kid was already in the street.  He ...
Did you know him?
No.  I'd seen him in there a few times before.  He was just a punk.  I'd never like danced with him or anything. Anyway, he was a thief.  He must've taken it from the statue.
Taken what?
The thing!  He was lying there in the street, moaning.  But he pointed at it ...
Wait a minute.  He was already ... wounded ... when you found him?
Yeah!  That's what I'm saying!  And it was lying next to him.  And he pointed at it before he passed out and ...
Wait.  Wait.  The chains.  Where did the chains come from?
That's what I'm trying to tell you! ...
Terri rummages in her bag, getting hold of something.
He said they came out of this.
She holds her hand out and the camera TRACKS in to meet i

Resting on her palm is a black cube about 4 inches square has the same matt-black carbonized look as the pillar and recognizable as one of the "carvings" we saw on it. There is fine filigree pattern-work over each of its surf and, to audiences familiar with the HELLRAISER movies, th is recognizable despite its black coating; it is the Lame Configuration, the puzzle box that opens the doors to Hel There is a stubby shard of material protruding from one s the box - presumably where the boy from ER had broken it the pillar.  Camera favors this jagged shard as we
VERY CLOSE on its upper left section.  We are looking at in the pillar that matches the pattern of the shard on th

The club is empty.  The dim lighting of working hours has replaced with the sickly gleam of one or two fluorescent and the club has that eerie not-quite-right look that all places have when subjected to a harsher light. Two WORKERS are in the final stages of clearing the night debris - emptying trash into big black plastic bags, wipi down tables and bars etc. Work completed, they head to the main exit. One of them hits the light switches so that the fluoresce clarity is again replaced by the more appropriate dim lig The other shouts across the apparently deserted club.
All done, Mr. Monroe.
They stand a second but no response comes.  The first tur the second and shrugs.
(mouthing silently) Ass hole.

His co-worker grins and they let themselves out. A beat.  Another door opens into the club and JP Monroe club's owner and the man we saw buy the pillar -  walks i the main room of the club from his private room at the ba JP walks out into the shadowed darkness of his small king He describes a circle around the dance floor, throwing gl at his odd sculptures, and finally walks into the center room to stand before the pride of his collection, the pil The pillar of course is stationary at this time, though i still mounted upside down. JP smiles possessively at the pillar - and then registers mutilation where the Box has been ripped away.
What the ... ?

He leans in closer to stare at the hole. Suddenly, jarringly, there is a quiet but distinct SQUEAK seems to come from within the hole. JP starts back a little, a small expression of anxiety on normally supercilious face.  He glances to right and left a grip, and leans forward again.

- as, again, the noise comes.  Is it a squeak - or is it creaking shifting of hidden machinery, hidden chains? JP's hand moves tentatively into shot, approaching the ho Slowly, slowly, it reaches wrist-deep into the blackness.
VERY CLOSE on JP's face - quizzical, enquiring ... and su contorted in pain!
Aaaaaahh!!

- as JP's hand whips out of the hole, shaking in shock an pain.  A rat is hanging on to one of JP's fingers, its sh teeth buried in the flesh! JP swings his arm violently through the air, dislodging t with the force of his swing.  A spray of blood is seen to from JP's wounded finger.
- as it lands heavily in a shadowed corner of the club an scurries away deeper into the darkness, squeaking furious
- as he looks down at his finger, face snarling.
Son of a ...
VERY CLOSE.  Blood seeps from the tiny teeth marks.
JP's voice is cut off by a strange SIZZLING NOISE heard O JP's face moves up to look at the pillar.  A look of awe shock crosses his face.

Some small drops of blood stand out bright red on the bla of the pillar.  The sizzling noise is coming from them. Suddenly the drops draw together magically into one large of blood - already larger than possibility would allow. it gets wierder; the blood suddenly dissipates into six o seven little rivulets that begin to run down the pillar. The streams of blood don't simply fall straight.  They se follow some pre-gouged pattern, running down the pillar t the blackened organic contours of the carvings. They all culminate at the point of Pinhead's chin - and t separate again, running over his frozen black face along carved scar lines that make a matrix across his features. When every canal line on the demon's face is filled neatl blood, a BLUE LIGHT seems to glow from within the pillar through Pinhead's face, giving it temporarily the blue to had enjoyed in (un)life.
CLOSE on his awe-struck face - bathed in reflected blue l
- as gradually the blueness subsides again, the visible b vanishing with it, leaving the same frozen implacable bla as before but charged now with a waiting power.

head_text.subj: INT. KITCHEN, JOEY'S APT. DAY, (NEXT MORNING)

text: (off) Oh my God ...

A frying pan sits atop a burner.  it contains the ugliest of scrambled eggs you have ever seen ... or perhaps it's omelette.  There are other ingredients in there but they' burnt so black they're unrecognizable.  At least half of mixture lies all over the stove top instead of in the pan
(off) Did I sleep through an earthquake?

- showing the chaos all around the kitchen: Spilled flour work surfaces; Egg-shells on the linoleum; A knocked-over of orange juice, the juice soaking into a piece of kitche roll; Coffee as black and thick as a mix of Indian ink an molasses.
Joey, in her dressing-gown, stands in the doorway with a shocked expression on her face. Terri, in an oversized man's shirt, stands by the stove h a fish-slice and smiling nervously.
I figured I'd make breakfast.
Right ... That's ... er ... that's nice of you, Terri.  Can I ask?  Is it always this ... exploratory?
Ha!  I don't know yet.  First time. Kitchen virgin, that's me.
Joey nods slowly, crossing to a cabinet and taking out so instant coffee.
I'll boil some water.
I'll do it!
No!  No, that's OK.  I like to.  I love boiling water.  It's a specialty of mine.  Why don't you go watch cartoons?
Joey watches Terri walk out of the kitchen, sighs in reli and grabs the kettle. INT.   MAIN ROOM, JOEY'S AP'T. Joey sits, drinking her coffee, as Terri walks round the with hers.
This is great.  And it's yours?  You like own it?
The bank owns it.  But I'm working on it.
Jeez, I've never owned anything.  I haven't even had a room of my own since I was fifteen years old.
How have you ... ?
Guys.  Sometimes friends.  Mostly guys.
Terri walks past Joey's TV set (sound down, cartoons play
The Box is on top of the TV.  In the warm light of mornin seems innocuous and harmless, like just another ornament.
- as Terri walks on, pausing by the shelves of books.
Wow.  Lotta books.  You read all these?
No.  I buy them to impress people.  Of course I've read them.
Cool.  I read a book once.  It was like all these people discovering who they used to be.  You know, like reincarnation?  It was really good.  You ever read that?
I don't think so.  But it's a fascinating subject.  Did you ...
But Terri has already moved on.  She is by the big pictur window.  The drapes are now open.
Great view!  Great view!  Look at this!
Joey stands and walks to join Terri.
Actually, I'm pretty familiar with the view ...
Joey's apartment is on a high floor and her window overlo many lower buildings, giving a view of the city beyond.
(off) ... but it is good.  You know, over to the left, you can ...
(looking to right and pointing) Who's that?

On the flat roof of a nearby building, a RETARDED TEENAGE sits motionless in an old rusty deck chair next to a smal Jerry-built pigeon coop.  Its door is open and it is empt The boy is some distance from the girls but his solitude, stillness, and the empty coop beside him lend the scene a atmosphere of sadness and loss. As Joey tells his story, we INTERCUT between the POV of t roof and the girls at the window.

I don't know his name ...  I saw the whole story.  A wounded bird was on his roof.  I could hear its cries from here. He went straight to it.  I couldn't've. I'd be frozen between pity and fear. But he wasn't.  Its pain spoke directly to him.  He picked it up.  Nursed it. Fed it.  And it got better.  Everyday he'd watch the pigeon.  Everyday the pigeon would watch him. I saw him learn. Learn that there was one more thing he had to do to make the rescue complete. And one day, just as afternoon became evening, he leaned over, opened the cage, and walked away.  Didn't look back.  But he heard the sound of its wings.
And he still sits there?
Every day.
Maybe he thinks it'll come back.
No.  He knows it won't.  It was his final act of love and part of him knows that and part of him doesn't yet.
Bullshit!  He should've kept it.  It'd live longer!  It's dangerous out there! People get hurt!
- as she realizes she has a wounded pigeon of her own.
What?  I wasn't talking about ... I ... Do you want to stay?  You want to stay here for a while?
Terri shrugs, gives a nervous smile. Joey crosses to the TV, picks up the Box and weighs it in hand.
OK.  OK.  It's a done deal.  But look  you have to help me.  I've got to solve this thing.  I've got to know what's going on.
Terri follows across the room and sits on the sofa.
But I don't know what's going on.
Maybe not.  But you know more than I do. You know something about this box. Something about a statue?
Yeah.  I found it.  I knew held like it and I figured ...
Woah.  Wait a minute.  Who?  The kid?
No.  JP.  My last boyfriend?  He like owns the club.  You know?  You were there?  He bought the statue.
That you found.  What do you mean you found it?

I was downtown looking for a ... a friend.  A guy I know.  Anyway, there was this store.  Like real old?  Lotsa weird shit in there.  I saw this statue. Pillar.  Thing.  I knew he'd love it. You've seen the club.
Would you know this store again?
Sure.  Why?
It's Saturday morning.  Let's go shopping.

Joey's Mazda 323 drives down the street. The daylight street is still creepy but in a different wa bums, no trash-can fires, nothing.  It has the feel of a town, as if nothing has breathed here for years.
Joey, at the wheel, has a disbelieving look on her face. Terri, smoking, flicks ash through her wound-down window.
Jesus.  Are you sure this is the street?
Yeah.  Happening, isn't it?
What on earth were you doing down here?
An evasive silence.
Terri?
Buying some drugs, alright?
Oh, Terri ...
For somebody else, alright?  Not for me. I don't do that shit anymore.
Then you shouldn't even be around it. You know, it's ...
Here!  Here!  Pull over!
Joey brings the car to a halt outside the antique store. Terri scrambles out of the passenger door.
Yeah.  See.  I told you it was here.
- as she looks at Terri from behind, her face worried for new and screwed-up friend.

Joey and Terri enter the store. The store is different, its selection of merchandise redu The 50's and 60's junk hardware is still there, along wit of the more mundane Victoriana, but it seems more "normal none of the odd items of punishment memorabilia are there Also, because it is daylight, the store seems merely old, interesting, and musty, not creepy or odd. There seems to be no-one in attendance.
- as they walk through the store.
(off) Can I help?

The voice startles the girls and they jump around to face counter as MAMA CARDUCCI moves into view from beneath it. Mama, an ancient and slightly eccentric Italian-American eyes the girls with the suspicion of somebody who hasn't customer in decades.  Not aggressive, just surprised.
Yes.  Thank you.  We were wondering ... Terri, show her the box.
Terri removes the box from her purse and holds it up.
No.  Sorry.  Not interested.  Not for my customers.  Have you tried ...
No.  No, you don't understand.  We're not selling it.  It came from here.  We want ...
Everything sold as is.  No guarantees. No returns.
No.  We want ...
I took back everything bought on a whim, I'd have no business.  I ...
Lady, will you shut the fuck up and give her a break.
A sudden silence.  Both Mama and Joey stare at Terri in surprise. Mama looks back at Joey.
Quite a mouth.  So what's the problem? You tell me.  You I like.
Joey smiles.  Terri raises her eyes to heaven.  Mama wait
Thank you.  This came off a ... statue? A pillar.  We wondered if you knew anything about the piece.  About where it came from.
Mama squints at the box, as if trying to recognize it.
Oh ... yeah.  Yeah.  That thing.  Ugly. Real ugly.  I sold that?
Mama's eyes scan the store.
Never mind.  I'm glad it's gone.  Made the store feel strange.  Who'd make such a thing?
Fine.  Fine.  But can you tell us anything about it?
It was part of a job-lot.  Some loony- bin they shut down.  Unclaimed stuff.
What else came with it?  Anything still here?
Sure.  Just papers, photos.  Stuff nobody'd ever want.
Can we see?
You gonna buy?
I don't know.  Maybe.
Right at the back there.  Middle shelves.  Coupla folders.  Nice stuff. I'd do you a good price.

Joey and Terri approach an old shelf unit along the rear A shaft of sunlight throws a square of light on the woode floor a few yards in front of the shelves. Joey takes up a big bulging manilla folder from the shelv begins to look through it.
Terri, check out the other folder.

Terri, still holding her purse and the box, looks around somewhere to put them.  All the shelves are full.  She la them on the floor in the square of sunlight and joins Joe the shelves, grabbing up the second folder.
What am I looking for?
God knows.  Anything.  Contacts.  Clues.
Terri opens up the folder and begins to pace the floor as flicks through the contents.
Jesus.  You're gonna pay her for this shit?  It's like fucking business papers for God's sake!
Bored, Terri wanders off to lean against another shelf-un

- as she flicks through the contents. Terri's dismissive summary seems justified.  All Joey see obscure and meaningless case-notes and paperwork.  Each i letter-headed THE CHANNARD INSTITUTE. Joey's hand reaches a large envelope.  Scrawled in hand a it is the phrase DR. CHANNARD - PERSONAL PAPERS.  Joey dr the contents out and begins to sift through them. The first item is a dusty, black-and-white photograph of officer in English Army uniform, circa 1920.  Joey blows dust from the photo.
- which sits on the floor in the shaft of sunlight, the d from the photo settling next to it.
The next photo is that of a beautiful young woman.  Joey it over.  Gummed on the back is a type-written slip that COTTON, KIRSTY  CASE NO.  5719.

The sounds of the girls flicking through papers is heard and then FADES as something strange begins to happen. Suddenly, the dust around the box begins to move as if bl an invisible wind.  It is drawn up so that it forms an impossible spiral in the air.  Spinning like a miniature hurricane, it hovers over the box.  The sunlight seems to brighter.  Is it just reflections on the metalwork design is the box itself glowing and shining?

- as her eyes flick back and forth as she scans ... Joey turns another item and her face registers surprise a she is seeing ... The next item in the folder is a Xerox sheet, a reproduct what appears to be an ancient document. It is a diagram, like a designer's drawing or plan.  And of the box seen from various angles.
- as she realizes what she is looking at.
(softly) Alright ...

Joey turns, folder in hand, to look at the box on the flo compare it to the diagram. Joey gasps. The miniature tornado of spiralling dust suddenly disappe inside the apparently sealed box as if sucked down into i As if on cue, the shaft of sunlight disappears behind a c as the last particle of dust disappears into the box. Joey, mouth open in shock, lets the folder drop from her The sound of its splayed contents hitting the floor alert Terri, who walks back round from the other shelf unit. Terri looks at the dropped contents and then up at Joey.
Joey ... ?
(still staring at Box) Help me pick 'em up, Terri.  I think the lady just made a sale.

head_text.subj: INT. MAIN ROOM, JOEY'S APT. EARLY EVENING

text: Joey is sitting behind a desk.  She has a phone in one ha a pen in the other. Spread out over the desk are various documents - the phot Kirsty, the diagram of the box, type-written transcripts and a scratch-pad on which Joey has scrawled several numb Joey is in mid-conversation on the phone.
Yeah ... yeah ... yeah ... No, it's important that I speak to ... What?  No, don't ...          (a beat)       Put. Me.  On.  Hold.  You.  Stupid.  Bitch.
Joey slams the phone down. She stares at the papers, at the scratch pad, takes a dee breath, and punches out a number on the phone. This time Joey's voice is different.

Hi.  Now listen.  And listen good.  I'm the Station Manager at W-QQY.  For the last half-hour you've been dicking around with my assistant.  Let me tell you something.  With or without your co- operation we are making this expose.  I assume you're smart enough to guess which version is going to make you look good.  Now, if you can't put one hand on that cassette and the other on a FedEx man's butt within thirty seconds then you damn well better put me through to somebody who can.
A pause while somebody jumps through hoops at the other e Joey's voice transmogrifies again; now it's a seductive, persuasive purr.
Dr.  Fallon?  How nice of you to take my call.  I understand you're in charge of video archive from the Channard Institute ... ?

Another night in Under The Underground Kids dance. Customers jostle at the bar. Couples neck in shadowed corners. Loud Metal music blasts out from speakers next to the var sculptures on the walls and ceiling. The center of the dance-floor is packed. The pillar is missing.

Sitting alone at a bar stool - though surrounded by tight packed customers - is SANDY, a very pretty teenage girl. is the same basic type as Terri; blonde, frail, young.  T young, in fact, to be legally in a club like this. Sandy stares at her empty glass - and stares at it wistfu enough to suggest she doesn't have the money to get it refilled.  She is trying to keep up a cool impassive face her eyes betray her basically vulnerable character.

Sitting at the opposite end of the bar, his eye-line conf he is looking at Sandy, is JP Monroe. The bar-stool beside JP is occupied by a TEENAGE BOY who his back to the bar and is talking to a GROUP of his FRIE JP has a speculative, predatory look on his face.  Withou shifting his gaze, he raises his hand and within seconds BARMAN is leaning over to hear his request. CLOSE on Sandy as a full glass is placed in front of her. alongside the glass is a beautiful long-stemmed red rose. Sandy looks surprised at the drink and then smiles in del at the rose.  She raises her eyes and looks across the ba JP returns the smile. He turns to the Boy beside him and murmurs something unhe The boy glances round, as if ready to argue with whoever speaking to him.  On recognizing JP, however, he vacates seat without an argument and stands to join his friends. JP looks back across the bar at Sandy and gestures at the stool beside him, an attractive welcoming smile on his fa Sandy gets up and, carrying the drink and the rose, makes way across to sit beside JP.
The deafening music playing in the club means that they h lean in close to hear each other speak.
Welcome.
You're JP Monroe, right?
Uh-huh.
And this is your club.  Great club.  I really love it here.  Great club.
Thank you.
Thank you for the drink.  And the rose. Wow.  That's ... really nice.
It's yours.  You won it.  It's a prize.
A prize?  For what?
You see, everyday I have my friend John here bring ...
The barman?  I thought he was called Rick?
He's a barman.  Whatever.  Do you mind if I continue?
I'm sorry.
Everyday I have my friend Rick here bring a newly-cut red rose in with him and keep it behind the bar.  And I award it to a woman of exceptional beauty.
Oh come on.  There're lots of girls here who look better than ...
Don't do that!  Don't put yourself down. If you have a quality, be proud of it...
While talking, and without taking his eyes off Sandy, JP gestures at the barman and their glasses.
... Let it define you.  Whatever it is. Most of the roses die behind the bar. This is the first I've given out for nearly a month.
No.  Really?
Two full glasses join the still half-full ones on the bar
Yes really.
Wow.  Thank you.
No.  Thank you.
Now there are six empty glasses on the bar and two half-f ones. ANGLE UP TO JP AND SANDY ... - except they're not there.  The two bar-stools are empty

The music OFF from the club is dull and muffled. JP1s private room is the size - and shares the general appearance of - an expensive studio apartment. His room looks like an annex to his club - black walls, b fittings, artworks of elegant cruelty - show that JP's ta for the bizarre is not just professional. Camera explores the room as the sound of BREATHING grows

- now the right way up, it stands in a corner of the room usual, it looks jarring and impressive but it doesn't rea seem out of place in JP's room. The Breathing OFF becomes mixed with MOANS and SMALL CRIE

JP and Sandy, both naked, are on the bed making love.  We maybe Sandy's making love.  JP's having sex. It is a selfish, phallocentric scene, concentrating on JP concern only for his own gratification.  It may be an ero sight, but it's not a pretty one. JP is on top.  He has hold of both Sandy's wrists in one hands and his body is working away rhythmically.  He is h upright, looking down at her.  No kissing. CLOSE on JP's face - his eyes open, staring down at Sandy CLOSE on Sandy's face - her eyes closed, half in pleasure in shame.

CLOSE on Pinhead's face.  Suddenly, horribly, the monster eyes fly open and his frozen face stares down at the love BLUE LIGHT seems to pulse from within the pillar, lending to Pinhead's face. Pinhead continues to watch the love-making until it comes climax. As JP GROANS out his orgasm and collapses forward onto Sa body, Pinhead's eyes close.  The BLUE LIGHT disappears an pillar is just the pillar again.

head_text.subj: INT. MAIN ROOM, JOEY'S APT. NIGHT

text: - FAVORING the telephone/answering machine, its red messa light blinking in the darkness of the apartment. Heard OFF is the sound of Joey coming in to her apartment doors opening and closing, bags being put down, footsteps Joey's hand comes into frame and presses the message butt
- as Joey waits for her machine and glances around the ro for Terri.
Terri?
The sofa is empty. Joey looks puzzled and is about to call again when the ma kicks in.

(on ansafone) Ms.  Summerskill.  Joanne.  Hello.  This is Dr. Fallon.  Martin.  Your reference material is on its way to you.  I very much enjoyed talking to you and I hope that if I'm ever in town you'll do me the honor of (sqwaaaaalk)
Joey has her finger on the fast forward button.
In your dreams, pal.
The chipmunk-squeal of Fallon's voice is replaced by the warning-beep of a second message.  Joey lets it play.
(on ansafone) ... your number from your resume. Which was very impressive, by the way. My name is Sharon Leech and you can reach me here at K-YZY in Monterey, area code 805 ... (sqwaaalk)
Joey stops the tape.
(to herself) Shit. Why now? Why not last week? Oh ...
She glances round at the empty room again, troubled by Te absence.  She crosses to her bedroom door.

Joey enters the darkened room - and then stops a few feet the door. Terri - lit only by the moonlight through the blinds - is on one side of Joey's bed fast asleep.  Apart from her sh which she has kicked off, she is fully dressed. Joey approaches the bed and watches her sleeping friend, face sympathetic, affectionate, and troubled. Joey reaches over, takes one of the pillows from the othe of the bed, and lays it at the bottom end. She slips off her shoes, shrugs off her jacket, and - delicately, carefully - climbs on to the other side of th laying her head on the pillow she had moved.
(whispered) Goodnight, Terri ...

JP, on his bed in his shorts enjoying a post-coital cigar blows smoke-rings at the ceiling and all but ignores Sand Sandy has put some of her clothes back on and is wanderin around the room, admiring it and chattering.
So cool ...
She approaches the pillar ... leans in close ... closer . ... nothing happens.
Radical.
She walks on to look at a painting on one of the walls.

It's a painstakingly rendered but crudely imagined piece. kind of crap you'd buy in a Melrose gallery. Perhaps it's called Biker Crucifixion.  Night-time, somew rural. A Hell's Angel, arms outstretched and stripped to waist, is tied to a tree by cruelly-tight barbed wire wra around his body.  At the foot of the tree his biker frien party, drink, and fuck, Harleys parked in the distance. crucified Angel's eyes are raised to the Moon.  He's smil
Wow.  You've got great taste.  This ... well ... this really says it, you know? It's really ... dark.
Still staring at the ceiling, JP pulls a pained face - li he's heard this embarrassing shit a hundred times.
Don't you think?
Mmn-hmnn.
Sandy turns to look at JP, troubled by his unresponsivene
Do you mind me talking about your stuff?
Unh-unh.
A beat.  Sandy stares at JP.  JP stares at the ceiling.
If it bothers you, just say so.
JP sighs.
It doesn't bother me.  I'm just not interested.
Oh.  Like I'm not an interesting person.

JP blows a smoke ring at the ceiling. Sandy walks back across the room to stand at the foot of bed.  ( And yes, fright fans, this does put her in front pillar - though hopefully the blossoming argument will di audience attention.)
But you gave me a rose ...
And tomorrow I'll give one to somebody else.  Get dressed.  Get out.
You shit.  Who do you think you are?
I'm JP Monroe, you stupid little bitch. Now get the fuck out of my life.
You ... I can't fucking believe you, you bastard!  You get me in here ...
Right.  Like you were hog-tied or something.
Look at you!  You think you're some God damn Prince or something.  With your shitty little Kingdom out there and all this ugly shi ....

Sandy is waving her arms to illustrate her point and, hal through her last line, has turned to indicate the pillar. Suddenly - BAM! BIG SCARE MOMENT! - two blackened arms fl from the center of the pillar and grab Sandy's gesturing The BLUE LIGHT burns from within, illuminating Pinhead's as his eyes open, filled with demonic glee and hunger. An impossible WIND begins to whistle through the room, as echoed glimpse of a storm in Hell. Sandy screams in mortal terror. JP jumps from the bed, cigarette falling to the floor.  H backs away to the opposite wall, face shocked, scared shi
Jesus Christ!
Pinhead smiles sardonically.
Not quite.

Pinhead's arms pull Sandy tight against the pillar and hi face, stifling her scream. JP flattened against the far wall, watches in horror as S held tight against the pillar, suffers a horrible death: Sandy's life-force is sucked from her.  Drawn into the pi Into Pinhead. It is a matter of seconds only but, in those few seconds Her body begins to collapse in on itself, turning grey an lifeless.  It is made worse by the fact that until the ve Sandy keeps struggling, writhing in the grasp of the mons The wind keeps blowing through the room. Finally, a dry lifeless husk, she is dropped to the floor The Blue Light fades from within the pillar. The wind disappears. The pillar is again black and stationary.  But its contou different, more rounded.  It looks more organic, as if sh its raw material into new alignments, new configurations. pillar seems to be in a process of becoming.  And the obv suggestion is that what it is becoming is Pinhead. Pinhead's head, arms, and torso now protrude from the pil They are not completely free and - now that the "eating" Sandy is concluded - seem incapable of independent moveme there is plainly a lot more of him than there was before. Even though the blue light has faded, Pinhead's face is noticeably different.  It is blue-tinged and more fleshy appearance.  Capable of movement.  And speech.
- who has sunk to the floor, staring at the pillar.
What ... What ... ?
What did you see?  The same as I. Appetite sated.  Desire indulged.  You saw the working of the world in miniature.
JP shakes his head in denial.  But he's already a little together than he was: after all, the pillar can't move an several yards from it.
That had nothing to do with the world. Not this one, anyway.
On the contrary.  It has everything to do with the world.  And our dreams of how it will succumb to us.  You enjoyed the girl?
Yes.
Good.  So did I.  And that's all ...
No!  No.  It's not the same ... I ...  No.  What you did ... it was ... evil.
Pinhead laughs.

How uncomfortable that word must feel on your lips.  Evil.  Good.  There is no Good, Monroe.  There is no Evil.  There is only the flesh and the patterns to which we can submit it.  You will help me to ...
JP shakes his head in furious denial.
No.  No no no.  No fuckin' way.  I'm gone ...
Grabbing at his jeans, JP heads out of his room.  Rapidly

head_text.subj: EXT. CITY STREETS, OUTSIDE CLUB NEXT DAY

text: The sun is high.  It's about noon. Like most clubs of its type, Under The Underground's exte is far from prepossessing.  It's set in an old brick ware in a run-down section of town. JP's Range Rover pulls up and JP gets out, carrying a lon black bag.  He glances round the all-but-deserted street enters the club.

CLOSE on Pinhead's face; in repose, back to its statue-li state. The sound of the door OFF opens the monster's eyes. JP enters, closing the door behind him. He doesn't look at the pillar.  He stays by the door and his eyes on the long black bag he has brought in with him He unzips it.  His manner is that of a man who has made a decision and is not about to listen to contrary argument.
(off) Another offering?
JP doesn't respond.  He draws a double-barrelled shotgun the bag, cocks it, and loads it. JP turns to face the pillar, drawing a bead on Pinhead. Pinhead's expression is wearily amused.
I'm touched ... That is the gun you used to kill your parents?
JP visibly staggers as Pinhead lets slip this knowledge. Pinhead smiles.
I understand.  Their fortune was so tempting, their affection so conditional.  What else could you do?
Fuck you!
He pulls the double trigger. A massive BLAST resounds around the room but that's about the 30 ott six is absorbed magically into the pillar.
Thank you.  Now, shall we talk sensibly?
JP lets the useless gun fall from his hand.
Don't flee from yourself.  If you have a quality, let it define you.  Cultivate it.  It is you.  By helping me, you will help yourse...
What!?  What are you talking about?  Why should I help you?

Because you want to.  You've always wanted to.  Look at your pictures.  Look at your sculptures.  Look at those tawdry representations and then ... Imagine.  Imagine a world of the body as canvas.  The body as clay.  Your will and mine as the brush and the knife. Oh, I have such sights to show you.
It's working.  JP's eyes are glittering with excited inte
What are you?
A dark star rising.  I was bound to another's system by a soul I once possessed.  A friend relieved me of that inconvenience.  Now I'm free.  Born again of Blood and Desire.
Hey, that's what makes the world go round.
Pinhead raises an amused eyebrow at JP's little joke.
You see, we're not so dissimilar.
But how in God's name ...
God?  My God was diamond and black light.  And I was his Dark Pope.  All that is changed.  A terrible beauty is born.  With a place at my right hand for a man of your tastes.
JP cruises the room, contemplating this.
How do we start?
It has already begun.

head_text.subj: INT. TV STATION, EDITING SUITE NIGHT

text: Many screens fill the frame, all of them crackling with s

Joey is alone at the control desk.  She has a video tape hand and feeds it into the master machine. She looks up at the still-ghosting monitors and then pres few buttons on the console. The snow is replaced by blackness on every monitor with a code ticking away at the bottom of each screen.
(softly) Alright ... Let's see what we got here.

The blackness on the monitors gives way to multiple image KIRSTY, the girl in the picture in the antique store. The video image is primitive, shot with a non-professiona camcorder, and is a simple medium long-shot of Kirsty, dr in a simple white smock, sitting in a hospital room. Kirsty addresses the camera directly, though occasionally up to the side as if speaking to an unseen doctor. INTERCUT through Kirsty's monologue between: A single mon image, the wall of monitors, and the watching and listeni Joey.

(on video) I don't know what the Box is.  But I know what it does.  I ...    (looks up to side)     I've said all this before. Do you ...    (blinks, nods, as if listening.  Looks back to camera)  I saw it open.  I opened it.  I saw what came out.  I don't know what else to call them.  Demons.  Demons live in the box. Or come through the box from somewhere else.  It's a gateway to Hell.  Or the South Bronx.     (smiles ruefully at her own joke.  Looks up to side as if chastised for kidding around.  Nods. Continues)     I know you don't believe me.  I know what it sounds like.  But what else ... Jesus, talk to Ronson, talk to the other cops.  They saw the house.  They saw my ... my father ...
Kirsty breaks down into sobs.
- whose expression shows distressed sympathy.  She too ha lost her father.
The video image breaks up into white noise and then comes in, as if the camcorder was turned off for a few moments. When the image returns, Kirsty is smoking a cigarette to calm her.

(on video) Solving the puzzle means opening the box.  Opening the box means opening doors.  And there are some doors you don't want to open.  And it may be metaphorical to you, Doctor, but you haven't had some blue-faced bastard come at you with hooks and chains.  It isn't delusion, it isn't psychosis.  It's reality.  It's reality.     (Pause. Long drag on the cigarette?)   Maybe not this reality ... but there are others. I've seen them.
Joey's face shows horrified fascination at Kirsty's story There is a conviction in the telling which is working on

head_text.subj: INT. MAIN ROOM, JOEY'S APT. NIGHT

text: The room is dimly-lit.
The floor is littered with video-boxes and tapes.  Other are piled on top of the VCR.  It's like somebody has been viewing constantly for a week and hasn't put anything awa

Many books are lying on the sofa, the table, and the floo Some are lying open, most are closed. Also on the coffee table are three different soft-drink c half- empty cup of coffee, and a very full ash-tray.

Terri is standing by the bookshelfs, running her eyes and finger along some titles. Now we understand the chaos in the room.  Terri's home al She's bored and trying to find something to hold her inte She looks away from the shelves and walks idly over to th The Box is back on top of the TV.  Terri's hand hovers ne on/off switch of the TV.  Then it hesitates and picks up box instead.  Terri holds the box and looks at it.  Her f becomes puzzled and she crosses the room to flick on a LI She wanders back to the TV looking at the box. It looks different.  Its edges are more sharply defined. shard where it was broken from the pillar is smaller, smo The detailed metal-work has some color back and is shinin
Jeez, Joey musta polished you up some. Sometimes I think she's wierder than me.

Terri's voice trails off as she continues to look at the She turns it in her hands, running her fingers over its filigree surfaces. TRACK in slowly as she cups it in both hands, her eyes mo from puzzlement to fascination and concentration. She rubs her thumbs over the designs.  TRACKING IN contin It's tense.  Is she going to try and work the puzzle? Suddenly .... BRRRRRRRRR ... the phone rings. Terri jumps in shock, nearly dropping the box. She puts the box back on top of the TV and crosses to the phone.  She picks it up.
Joey?
(on phone) Not quite.
JP?
Live and in the flesh.  How're you doing, babe?
What do you want?
CLOSE on JP's face as he speaks into a phone.
God, always questions.  What do I want? I don't want anything.  Just concerned about you.  Just checking in.
Yeah right.  How'd you get this number?
Will you relax?  Your little girlfriend left a card, remember?
Oh.  Yeah.  Yeah.  Well ... I'm fine. Things are great here.  Joey's going to get me a job at the TV station.  I'm meeting lotsa new people.  It's really great.
Really?
Yeah really.  I'm ...
No.  I mean, really?  Because I'm concerned for you, sweetheart.  I care about you.  I guess I miss you.  I'm sorry we split up.  I'm sorry I ...
You're apologizing?
Hey, it has been known.  C'mon Terri, I'm not that bad a guy.  I have regrets. I'd like to put things right.  Don't tell me you haven't thought about me. Huh?
Well ... of course I have.  I've thought.  I've ... Oh, JP, you were so horrible.  You really hurt me ...
I know.  I know.  It's bad.  I'm a bad person.  But I try not to be, Terri.  I really do.  And I really miss you.
I miss you too.
That's so good to hear, sweetheart.  It really is. You know, I .. are you alone?
Yes.
Good ... Good ... Look, why don't you come over?  You know, nothing heavy, little drink maybe, little talk.  Just see how we both feel?
Oh, I don't ...
C'mon.  It'll be great.

head_text.subj: INT. MAIN ROOM, JOEY'S APT. NIGHT

text: CLOSE on Terri's face - we can almost see her summon the power to refuse.
No!  No.  I can't.  I just can't.
She slams the phone down quickly before he can persuade h She takes a couple of deep breaths and walks away from th phone.
Shit.  Shit.  Shit.  Shit.  Shit.
She looks around.  She looks at the books.  She looks at videos.  She looks at the table.  She looks back at the p
- as it RINGS again.
- shakes her head and turns the ansafone on. After two rings, the machine responds.
(ansafone message) Hi.  You've reached Joanne Summerskill. In spirit at least.  Please leave a message.  Thanks.

(on phone) Hello.  Ms. Summerskill, this is Sharon Leech again from K-YZY in Monterey. Sorry to call so late but I was wondering if you got my other message? Look, I probably shouldn't say this on tape but what the hell ... there's a job here if you want it.  Late-night news reader.  We think you'd be marvelous ..
The machine BEEPS and cuts her off, leaving the message l FLASHING. CLOSE on Terri's face - disappointed and sad.

head_text.subj: INT. TV STATION, EDITING SUITE NIGHT

text: Joey is still at the desk watching the bank of monitors. As Kirsty speaks, INTERCUT between Joey and the monitors.

(Looks to side)  Again?  (Shrugs. Looks back at camera)  The box.  I don't know where it came from.  I don't know who made it or why.  I only know what it does.  It hurts.  It hurts.   (Looks off to side as if listening.)  How?  (Looks back)  I don't know.  It kind of opens itself.  Your fingers move.  You learn. It wants to open, that's the thing.  And it knows when you want to open it.  And it helps.  And it opens.  And then they come.  The Cenobites.  The demons.

Multiple images of Kirsty speaking those last few lines. Suddenly, one - and only one - of the monitors suffers a NOISE WIPE-OUT. Joey glances up at the one ghosting monitor, puzzled - an freezes in shock.

- as, on the one monitor, a new image suddenly appears: A hazy, black-and-white image (very grainy, like early experimental TV images) of a thirtysomething man in early twentieth century military uniform. The man - ELLIOTT - stares directly out of the monitor sc and, just as Kirsty finishes her last line ("The cenobite demons."), he speaks (in an English accent).
(on monitor) She's telling the truth, Joey.
Another BURST of WHITE NOISE and the image is gone. Kirsty is back on that monitor, just like all the others.
Look, you can have me tell this ...
Joey remains staring at the haunted monitor, numb with sh What the hell is going on? Kirsty's voice plays OFF as Joey stares.

...  as often as you want.  There's not going to be any breakthrough.  You might think it's delusion, but it's not.  I saw them.  I looked into their eyes and they looked back at me.  Creatures from Hell.
A late-night coffee-shop in the early hours of the mornin Classic American Diner.

Empty booths. A quiet counter.  A COP perches on a stool drinking coffe A TRUCKER in a booth by himself bites methodically on a d his eyes staring off into the vacancy of the night. In a corner booth, FOUR KIDS nurse cokes and smoke cigare
A black coffee sits by an ash-tray holding a burning ciga
- sitting at the table staring at the coffee. She waits.  She takes a drag on the smoke.  She waits.  S sips her coffee.  She waits.  She looks up across the din
The double doors of the diner's entrance.
She looks back down at her coffee. The sound of doors opening OFF.  Terri looks up again.
A WALKING POV as somebody approaches Terri, whose face br into a nervous, ambiguous smile of welcome.
- as JP walks confidently to her table, smiling.
Hey, babe.  Thanks for coming.
JP sits down opposite her.  He reaches over and pats her

head_text.subj: INT. MAIN ROOM, JOEY'S APT. NIGHT

text: Joey enters the unlit main room.  She glances across at t sofa.  It's unoccupied.  Joey puts the light on. She grimaces at the chaos of the room - the piles of vide books - and crosses the room to the bedroom door.  She op the door and looks in.
Terri, we can't bunk up every night! People will ...
The bedroom is empty, nobody on the bed.
(off) ... talk.  ... Terri?
Joey leaves the door and walks back into the main room. She looks around and then walks over to the phone.  Somet has caught her eye.
A hand-scrawled note by the phone reads ENJOY MONTEREY, Y LIAR. JOEY registers the note.
Oh shit.
Joey shakes her head sadly.  What can she do?  It's the e hours of the morning.  She has no idea where Terri is.  S walks back to the bedroom and closes the door behind her.

Thick green jungle foliage obscures the view of a POV cam The sounds of confused battle are heard OFF; helicopters, fire, distant explosions, screams of the dying and the wo Leaves and branches SMACK against the frame as the unseen dreamer rushes confusedly through the dense forest. The voices of the Soldiers - distant, echoed, repeated - heard over the roar of battle.
(off) He's going.  He's going.  He's going ...
(off) We're losing him.  We're losing him. We're losing him ...

The sound of their voices seems to prompt the POV camera more furious endeavor. It turns rapidly left and right, forcing its way through greenery until suddenly, with one last push through folia thick enough to be a single bush, the view changes comple

The POV camera (Joey) walks out into another battlefield, of a different character. It appears to be early morning.  The skies are grey and overcast.  In the distance plumes of black smoke spiral u No jungle, no trees or grass.  The ground is baked mud disfigured with deep trenches, re-inforced by wooden slat The atmosphere is post-conflict; guns are silent, there a cries or sound of machinery. Scattered around are corpses of many khaki-clad soldiers. Nothing moves.  No birds sing.  It is a horrible, desolat image from the bloody pages of history.  The fields of Fl in World War One. A noise begins to be heard OFF.  A low angry BUZZING.
A cloud of buzzing flies are feeding on the flesh of his dead face.
(off) Noooooooooo .......
The buzzing and Joey's anguished cry both CONTINUE OVER a
Joey sitting up in bed, eyes wide, still screaming.
Nooooooooooo!

The cry cuts off abruptly as Joey realizes where she is. She catches her breath and then freezes as she realizes t the buzzing sound from her dream is present in her bedroo Are the flies still feeding?  She glances around her room
Her TV set is on.  The buzzing sound comes from white noi Joey is puzzled and scared.
Is somebody here?  Is somebody here!? Terri ... ?
She half gets out of bed and then stops, transfixed, as t screen's white noise is replaced by an image.

As in the editing suite, the image is grainy black-and-wh The buzzing continues, now joined by HISSING and WHISTLIN fades in and out as if unseen hands are trying to tune in impossibly distant station. Somewhere in the sound-montage we can almost hear GHOSTLY VOICES whispering; "Joey, Joey, Joey ... " On the screen, an English Officer - Elliott - is sitting legged on the floor of a Quonset hut. On the floor in front of him is something at which he sta something that the image is not sharp enough to show.
Fear vies with fascination in Joey's expression.
What ... What's going on?  What's happening?
The image disappears in a burst of STATIC which in turn i replaced by another image, still monochrome and grainy; A and-shoulders of Elliott, staring directly out of the scr
You have to help me, Joey.

A burst of STATIC and the image disappears completely. Th is obviously not turned on.  The room is silent. Joey stares at her dead TV in numbed silence. She falls back into bed, pulling the covers protectively her, staring at the ceiling.
A CLICK is heard OFF and the room is lit, REVEALING JP by door, his finger by the light-switch.  He smiles into the and walks in, looking behind as Terri hesitates by the do
Come on in.
Terri moves past him. JP locks the door with a key he draws from his pocket. Terri registers this.  JP calms her.
Not a good neighborhood.  People disappear.  (a beat)  Feel like home? It's just like you left it.
Terri moves into the room, glancing around herself cautio She registers the pillar.
It's plainly different from the last time Terri saw it bu despite what the audience knows about it - it still seems inanimate; a black frozen carving, disturbing but harmles
Not quite.  This wasn't here.
No.  But, as you can see, I'm having some work done on it.  You found a real treasure for me, Terri.  I hope I can show you how grateful I am.
Yeah ... yeah, it looks different.
Yeah, a girl I know helped smarten it up.  Put her heart and soul into it.
A girl?  Anyone I should know?
Not now, no.  I mean - now that you're here, it's like she doesn't even exist, you know what I mean?
JP has been cruising the room as they speak.  Now he's st close to the pillar.  Terri is still some distance from h
Yeah right.  Look ...

Terri, listen.    (a beat)   Why don't you come here and kiss me?  I mean, it's probably ticking away in both our minds, right?  Is it going to happen?  Isn't it going to happen?  Let's get it out of the way.  See how we feel.  Then we can relax.  Talk.  You know.
A pause - a tense one for the audience who know that JP h obviously decided who Pinhead's next meal is.  Terri look JP, half suspicious, half attracted.
I don't think so.  Not yet.  I'm not ready yet.
Sure.  Sure.  I understand.  It's cool. I mean, we've got all night.
JP smiles winningly and warmly.  A nice guy.  A nice smil smile a girl can trust. The pillar stands behind him, its dark inhabitant still a silent, waiting for the sacrifice.

Series of shots (maybe all CROSS-FADED) of kids dancing a drinking in the club to establish the passing of time - a highlight the tension of the scene in JP's room by its proximity to this (relative) normality.

head_text.subj: INT. JP'S PRIVATE ROOM NIGHT, (MINUTES LATER)

text: JP lounges against his wall, smoking, close to the pillar Terri is sitting on the bed.  She's upset.  She's been te JP about Joey and the phone message.
That's terrible.  What a bitch.  She was obviously just using you, Terri.  Ready to dump you the second she had what she needed, interfering little whore.
No.  It isn't ... she wouldn't ... It's like I must have done something wrong, you know?  Freaked her out.  Just fucked up something good again.
Hey, you didn't fuck it up with me.  You know that.  It was my fault, babe, it really was.  And you know I'm sorry. And I'm sorry to see you upset now.  I hate to see you in pain like this.
Terri looks up at him, her eyes vulnerable, on the verge tears.  She really wants to believe that he's being a nic
Really?
Yes!  God, yes.  I ... I just want to hug you.  To hold you.  To tell you it's alright.
God, the bastard's good at this.  Terri breaks into small and holds her arms out for him.

No.  No, sweetheart, you come to me. It's not fair.  I come over there.  You know.  We're on the bed.  I just ... 'cos you know how much you excite me. God, just looking at you.  You're so beautiful.  I come over there and I'd just want to touch you.  Feel you.  Kiss you.  And that isn't what this is about. C'mon, babe, come to daddy.  Let me make it better.

Terri wipes her eyes, gives a small shy smile and stands She's walking toward JP.  And the pillar. JP puts a hand out.  He smiles.  Re-assuring.  Loving. Terri walks.  Vulnerable.  So in need of reassurance and
She's getting closer ... closer ... closer ...

- as he blows it.  A sidelong glance at the pillar?  A su naked hunger in the smiling eyes?  A single bead of sweat Some tiny little thing that takes the lid off his game. Terri stops dead.  She doesn't know what's happening but suddenly this doesn't feel right.
No ... Wait a ...

JP, smiling mask wiped off, leaps at Terri. Terri flings herself backward, screaming in shock and fea Pinhead: suddenly animate and furious; eyes wide open, fa contorted in frustrated rage, black arms clawing at the a
Bring her to me, boy!

A furious, confused scene of tension and struggle. JP has hold of Terri, trying to drag her to the monster. Terri fights back, screaming her disbelief and struggling kicking against him.  They are perilously close to the pi Pinhead is furious - roaring, tearing at the pillar with hands as if trying to physically rip himself. free of it. Slowly, JP's size and strength is telling; Terri is being dragged nearer and nearer to the demon. At the last possible second - when it seems it's all over Pinhead's snatching fingers are centimeters from Terri's - Terri snatches up a heavy ornament from a shelf by the and smashes JP right across the head with it. JP collapses semi-conscious at the foot of the pillar. Terri throws herself back from the monster's grabbing arm Pinhead snarls in frustration, hands clenched in fists of

Terri - safely feet away from the pillar - stands, shakin breathless, eyes wide in horror and shock as she stares a creature from nightmare. And suddenly Pinhead changes tack; he slides from the roa beast of a moment before to his more usual persona - the articulate Black Pope of Hell.
Wait!  Why run?  Where to?  Do you know where you are?
You're at the door of dreams.  And you can open it.
What are you talking about?

There are two keys in this room.  On is in the pocket of this fool.  You could take it out without me reaching you. (a beat)  Probably.  And you could use it to let yourself back in to the world you know.  The world you've always known; banal, hopeless, dreamless.
Pinhead, as ever, is hitting the right buttons.  Terri, a know, has dreamed of dreaming.
And ... like ... the other?
The other is the key to dreams.  To a world of black miracles and dark wonder. Another life of unknown pleasures.  It's yours.  Complete the pattern.  Solve the puzzle.  Turn the key.
- as she looks at the monster.  And smiles.
Where is it?
Pinhead returns the smile.
It's lying bleeding at your feet.
JP is on the floor, semi-conscious, bleeding from the hea
(delerious. Ad-lib) Unhhh ... Terri ... what ... no ...
Terri edges around the pillar to grasp one of JP's limp a

- as the bond between tempter and tempted is strengthened Terri holds JP's arm out ... Pinhead stretches his own arm forward ... And JP finally - for one brief second of terrifying clari realizes what's happening.
(screaming) No! Terri! Please! I didn't mean to..!!

Too late.  Pinhead's hand closes around his wrist. Terri leaps back out of harm's way. Pinhead - with awesome strength - yanks JP up to his feet pulls him close.  He stares into the terrified face of JP
I have such sights to show you.
JP is sucked dry by Pinhead. And Terri watches, her face perversely excited by this - first of the dark miracles that the monster had promised.
- as the transformation of pillar into Pinhead is complet

Pinhead, fully-fleshed and incarnate, stands in the room. his feet are the dry husk that was JP and the steaming, h remnants of the pillar like a pool of black toxic oil. He turns and looks at Terri.  Slowly, elegantly, he walks toward her. Terri backs away across the room.  But she backs off slow sensuously, like an eager but nervous virgin bride ready her groom. Camera moves in CLOSE on her glowing eyes and excited fac

head_text.subj: INT. MAIN ROOM, JOEY'S APT. NIGHT

text: CLOSE on the Box.  A cloud of dust spirals out into the r a reverse action of the dust in the antiques store.

CLOSE on Joey's sleeping face.  REM shows beneath her eye and she murmurs in her sleep. Very faintly OFF is the sound of distant music. Joey's eyes snap open and glance from side to side.  She up in bed and registers the music, which seems to have gr volume on her waking. It is strange, old-fashioned music;  A palm-court string orchestra playing a sentimental waltz tune reminiscent of 1920's or earlier. Joey looks around the room. There is no-one in the room.
